Eventhough 54 Mb/s is now the standard, most internet connections are not able to even come close to maxing out the 'old' 11 Mb/s, so you could just as well stick to your old rig.

 I actually switched from 802.11b (11Mb/s) to 802.11g (54Mb/s) not because of the data rate but because other differences in signalling between the two make g a bit better at dealing with obstacles. In my case a big blob of plumbing was creating dead spots in the master bedroom, but those have practically gone away since the switch. On the other hand, reception downstairs is a little worse than before due to range. Neither of these differences are so much a matter of the technology itself, but rather relate to the units that are being produced (e.g. power levels, different antenna types). As new technologies such as MIMO (multiple in, multiple out) are refined they'll show up on g units but probably never on b. I got an entire Netgear 802.11g setup with a router/AP and two laptop cards for $70 after rebates, so there's not much reason to shy away from it.
